Get a notepad or a piece of paper and write all the good things you see in him. Then write some good things you see in his fiance and why you honestly think she's good for him. Could be the smallest thing ever. No need to make it funny or anything, although it's a plus to have a light joke in there somewhere. From there you write a short monologue starting with the things you appreciate in your brother, then the fiance, then you close with your best wishes to them as a future husband and wife. If you don't know his fiance that well you can also say things like how you hope she can deal with the small things your brother lacks in instead of the things you'd say about her. Maybe he sucks at dishes or whatever. To make it funny. What always helps is to just start writing down stuff you might want to say, anything that comes to mind. No matter how shitty you think it is. When you're done you look at the things you wrote down and filter out the things you don't like. Refine the things you do like and repeat until you're satisfied. Then write a short speech from those things.

Maybe look up a youtube tutorial on how to write a speech like this as well if you're still struggling. Good luck anon.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>27831485
Being socially retarded is a major part of it. It may not be blatantly obvious to yourself or even others that you are socially retarded though. Often people will think they can't be autistic because they know the basics of social interaction, but that isn't true, plenty of autists know that.

It's also very common for autists to have sensory issues. The most stereotypical ones are struggling with fluorescent light or with the brightness outdoors, certain sounds, certain textures of food or certain fabrics in contact with skin. It could feel painful, or it could just be agitating or make you anxious, in that case it may even be hard to realize you have these problems.
But sensory issues go far beyond the most stereotypical that people usually bring up. For example, you could be clumsy, you could enjoy spicy food, you could fail at noticing things in front of you, you could easily get dizzy, and the list goes on.

Additionally, it's very common for autists to make motions called "stimming". The stereotypical may be hand flapping and rocking back and forth, but it's very often more subtle like that. I'm often wiggling my toes, you could grind your teeth, and I think your random jumps and excited running might also be considered stimming.

Also, you can look at what you did when you were a kid. Did you sort your toys? That's typical autism. I sometimes sorted the Duplo bricks by color and type, for example.
And what you did as kid is often more revealing anyway, because having done it as a kid is enough for it to count towards your autism, even if you no longer do it.

You should look up some traits and see if you fit, either currently or when you were younger.

Since then, we've been having a lot of sex, both AM and PM. She told me she noticed I was putting in more effort and she appreciates it. But last night we didn't have sex and she had a full crying meltdown. She said that she's the only one who ever initiates. I first asked her why that matters and then reminded her that I have initiated all of the AM sex, which makes up about half of our activity in the past week. She ignored that and said that we never have spontaneous sex and that it has to be planned. I reminded her that AM sex is spontaneous and never planned and that her requirement for sex right before bed makes it difficult.

She told me she needs to be desired and that she was very clear about what she physically needed. I reminded her we've had sex 3/4 days, which is more than she asked for AND also that she said she saw me making an effort less than 2 days ago.

The other matter is that when we do have sex, there is a great deal of expectation and pressure from her that makes me anxious. She gets angry if I don't finish. She gets angry if I say the wrong word while dirty talking.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
Don't get lost in the specifics, just stop arguing about them. Yeah you are right that initiating in the morning counts as initiating - obviously - but she's not being like this because she is 100% convinced that she initiates 100% of the time but because she feels insecure and rejected. And unfortunately, for most people in the heat of the moment being technically proven wrong does not necessarily stop you from feeling that way.

Try to break the negative emotional spiral. Come to her with reassurance about how attractive you find her at a moment she's not looking for it. Put the topic aside for a day or two. Then discuss it calmly and really focus on the practicality: you are only a human being and you only have so much energy. If she wants to have a lot of sex she needs to be willing to compromise and either have sex earlier in the day or have sex with you in the night, then do her own thing for a bit and then come to bed to sleep.

Again don't bother trying to make her see how reasonable the request is. Just tell her this is the only way it'll work. That's what matters and once the conflict is (more) resolved, your positions will soften too and it is much easier to admit or see you were not being reasonable before.

There is nothing wrong with agreeing on a certain moment of the day (for a specific day I mean, like "let's have sex tomorrow night"). That might also help you initiate. If it can take you longer to get in the headspace but you can get hype yourself with fantasy/anticipation, you can suggest a later time to be together and then start looking forward to it.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.sub: Good topics for talking to a woman
threads.com:
So for the first time in my life I actually grew some balls and walked up to some women sat on a table near us at the bar. Felt like I'd just scare them off but it actually went fairy well and we managed to enjoy each others company for a bit. I think I might have started acting a bit autistic towards the end and ruined it. But it's helped my confidence and I feel like overall i did okay considering it was my first time. Now knowing I have it in me, and I can learn from my mistakes for next time.

So long story short I'm asking 2 things. What are some good conversation starters when talking to someone new? I know the typical stuff like ask about jobs and hobbies, but what can start a deeper conversation that makes you stand out more, while not being too overwhelming for a stranger to ask.

And my second question. What are generally socially acceptable settings to strike up conversation with a stranger? I know bars are fine, I know on the train is weird. But what about places like cafes or public parks?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
For starters, make a (preferably funny) comment on what's happening at that very moment, rather than using a pre-rehearsed conversation topic or pickup line - it comes across way more natural. Asking people out of the blue what their hobbies are is creepy, but image you see someone finishing a beer and looking vaguely annoyed, you could just simply say "You look like you could use another one of those" and then casually go about your business like you never expected an answer anyway.

Once a conversation does get going, general topics are totally acceptable however. The key here is to show genuine interest, rephrase what they are telling you in a way that shows you are listening and understand without simply repeating it word for word, and asking questions that allow them to elaborate (but only on topics they are clearly passionate about).

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>27830114
Wait until you get a job offer. Then, if you are still waiting on other employers to get back to you, immediately send a message letting them know that you have a job offer and ask if they can expedite your application.

Usually after an employer makes you an offer, you have like a week or more to decide. Ask them how long you have before you give them an answer to accept and send messages out to the other employers during that time letting them know you got an offer and see if they are willing to give you an answer sooner. If you don't hear back from the others before you run out of time to accept your offer, it could mean that they are not that interested in you. At that point you would have to decide whether or not to take the offer but at least you would know where you stand.

Alternatively, one of those other employers could respond back with an offer of their own and then you would have multiple offers to choose from.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>27828696
Yes, and that experience comes in many varieties too.

The more losers you’re around, the more comfortable you are with being one. There’s no one around, whose superior being shines a light onto your own shortcomings. It’s those once in 5 years encounters where you are given an opportunity, that unfortunately you are in no position to seize. And the dark reality is that you eventually make yourself comfortable with that too.

I think one of the core issues is identity. The identity is the cabin of safety. It’s what can you relate to, what can you see yourself in, what do you feel comfortable with. What kind of people do you feel comfortable around. Where do you feel you belong. If you ask yourself these questions, and compare it to the life you’ve created, isn’t the resemblance shocking?

For example, if you feel like you’re a loser, then having aspirations is going to be very anxiety inducing, and you’re going to feel like an idiot for telling your friends what you want, because it’s almost a foregone conclusion that a loser like you will never get that. Keep your expectations low, so there’s not so far to fall.

That identity, the thoughts and emotions you have, only perpetuate because they’re where we feel at home. But as you start to study what those thoughts and feelings are, you start to understand that these thoughts and feelings aren’t you. They can’t be you, because you’re looking at them, you’re something more than that. When you feel exhausted, and you decide to relax, and become familiar with that sensation, you have to be willing to live inside of it, then you cease to be mastered by exhaustion, and instead you are the master. The more you live in constant touch with it, the more you discover yourself outside of it. You find a part of yourself that feels very alive, and has plenty of energy in the midst of that exhaustion.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>27828940
And you can do that with all emotions.

You can do it with the feeling that you are a loser. You can do it with anxiety. With the feeling that you are failing. You can get over any emotion, if you will accept it enough to live inside it and stop running from it, because then you are bound to find the part of you that is MORE than that emotion. And then you gain the ability to choose what you want to be instead. That’s a straight up rebirth

Last week, my friend finally dropped a hint, that they're breaking up, and consequently that we wouldn't be spending the new year together. Later i've found that they've actually been broken up about a month and were keeping it from us. He's literally helping her set up a new apartement, so they're splitting up amicably.

Ever since i've found out, i've been over-the-top anxious about losing her as a friend. When they were together, i always viewed her just as a friend, but now that they've broken up, i'd see it as acceptable(even if extremely remotely), of being together with her. Losing her as a friend and or losing her from my life just feels very bad. I don't know what i'm feeling here, but i'm feeling pretty terrible.

I'm very much thinking i would regret not shooting my shot with her, even if it's a long one, but before i would even consider that, i'd need to get a blessing from my friend who broke up with her.

I don't have a clue how to even begin approaching this, but the anxiety has been become extremely overbearing. I haven't ever felt like this for such a long time.

I'm not even sure who i could speak to, about this. Does anyone have any similar experience of dealing with something like this? Will this pass? Would the risk of messing up my friendships that exist currently is too great?

I did a 6x2 contract, six years serving then two in IRR on "standby" if the draft or some shit kicked in. I wish I had just done four years or so of active duty instead. I was so young, I didn't move into and/or advance in the career I was looking at. The time to "focus on your civilian life/career and military shit at the same time" never came. It was more like half assing two things at once.
I say just go active duty. You still get some shit for college. The Army gets boners over that fucking shit, especially because you get promotion points for degrees. Go active. Use the college benefits for some online classes and bang out a degree in four years like everybody else. You'll still only be 24 when you get out, with a degree, with vet preference if you're in that sort of state, have military experience on your resume etc.

I love the time with the boys. The fuckery that makes for good stories. It's why I'm still in. Doing it on the side. But if you really just want college out of it, go active. No distractions, online classes. Get it done and come back home with a degree. If anything pick a technical MOS, or go active Air Force so the emphasis on college and free time for classes is emphasized.

I work in HR so believe this.

Job listings are wish-lists, describing the ideal candidate. If he shows up, great. If not, they take the best of those who do show up.
